Lesson Narrative

Building on the informal language students have used so far in the unit, the purpose of this lesson is for students to understand that sequences are functions and to use function notation when defining them with equations. In previous lessons, they described the arithmetic sequence 99, 96, 93, . . . as starting at 99 where each term is 3 less than the previous term. Now they think of it as a function \(f\) of the position, starting at position 1, and write \(f(1)=99\) and \(f(n)=f(n-1)-3\) for \(n\geq2\), where \(n\) is an integer. This is called a recursive definition for \(f\) because it describes a repeated, or recurring, process for getting the values of the sequence—namely, the process of subtracting 3 each time. Students will use recursive definitions to describe functions in both mathematical and real-world contexts throughout the remainder of this unit. It is not necessary that they use the term “recursive definition,” however.

Throughout this unit, definitions of sequences written in function notation are always followed by an inequality that describes the domain of the function, which is particularly helpful when students work with definitions for the term of a sequence and need to indicate what the first term of the sequence is. This is not meant to imply that all students should use such inequalities every time they define a sequence using function notation. In your classroom, it may be better to ask students to write out in words, instead of inequalities, the restrictions on the domain of a sequence.

Keep the focus on writing equations and tell students to be prepared to respond orally when asked about the domain of a sequence.

The goal of the lesson is for students to practice interpreting and writing recursive definitions of functions while also representing functions in different ways. Students match sequences and recursive definitions in a matching activity, giving them opportunities to explain their reasoning and critique the reasoning of others. An important part of the activities is giving students time to share and explain their strategies for matching and creating different representations. This helps emphasize that there is often more than one way to approach problems. It also helps establish that sharing strategies and learning from other students are classroom norms.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Comprehend that sequences are functions whose domain is a subset of the integers.
  • Create (in writing) a recursive definition for a sequence using function notation.
  • Create a table, graph, or recursive definition of a sequence from given information.
  • Determine what information is needed to represent a sequence in different ways. Ask questions to elicit information.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Define arithmetic and geometric sequences recursively using function notation.
  • Represent a sequence in different ways.
  • Ask questions to get the information needed to represent a sequence in different ways.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A12(C) identify terms of arithmetic and geometric sequences when the sequences are given in function form using recursive processes;

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 4.16.1: Define a Sequence
  • 4.16.2: What Is a Recursive Definition?
    • 4.16.2: Self Check
    • 4.16.2: Additional Resources
  • 4.16.3: Ways to Represent a Sequence
    • 4.16.3 Self Check
    • 4.16.3: Additional Resources
  • 4.16.4: Geometric Recursive Definitions

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 4.16.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graph paper
  • Pre-printed slips, cut from copies of the blackline master, card sort

Required Preparation

  • Cut card sort for activity (enough for each pair).

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

  • geometric sequence
  • arithmetic sequence

New Vocabulary

  • recursive definition

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their creativity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Compound Interest
  • Finding Flow

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Creativity from Character Lab.
